entry.content:
Katie Paul 和 Sheila Dang，为路透社报道，“ 当超过一半的用户离开应用程序时，Meta 计划为线程保留‘挂钩’ ”：

Meta Platforms 首席执行官马克·扎克伯格 (Mark Zuckerberg) 周四对员工表示，该应用程序在推出后几周内就失去了一半以上的用户，因此该公司的高管们将重点放在提高 Twitter 新竞争对手 Threads 的留存率上。扎克伯格在公司内部市政厅发表讲话时表示，这款基于文本的应用程序的用户保留率比高管预期的要好，尽管它“并不完美”。路透社听到了该讲话的音频。

“显然，如果有超过 1 亿人注册，理想情况下，如果他们全部甚至一半都坚持下来，那就太棒了。我们还没有到那一步，”他说。扎克伯格表示，他认为这种下降是“正常的”，并且随着公司为该应用程序添加更多功能（包括桌面版本和搜索功能），预计保留率将会增长。

当然，在最初的涌入之后，使用量将会下降。当实体店和餐馆成功开业时，没有人会想到开业客流量不会下降。从各方面来看，尽管 Threads 是全新的且尚未提供 Web 界面，但它每天仍拥有数千万用户。

[旁注：有点郁闷的是，在普通人看来，网络应用程序就等同于“桌面” 。但这并不奇怪。人们希望在台式计算机上使用 Threads，对他们来说，这意味着在网络浏览器中输入“threads.net”。]

但 Threads 已经失败的说法在周末盛行：

  • Ars Technica ：“注册 Threads 的 1 亿人中大多数都停止使用它”
  • 《纽约邮报》 ：“马克·扎克伯格的帖子陷入困境，埃隆·马斯克宣称 X 用户数量创历史新高”
  • 内部人士：“报告称，超过一半的注册线程的人已经停止使用它，这促使马克·扎克伯格推动‘挂钩’来吸引用户”

Dare Obasanjo 在 Threads 上写道，完美地反驳道：

认为一款显然是 MVP（最小可行产品）的应用程序没有 1 亿活跃用户就是失败的想法是科技媒体给我们带来的那种愚蠢的想法。

科技媒体只能写 3 个故事：

  • 这家公司是成功的
  • 这家公司是失败的
  • 看看这家公司获得了多少资金

可以说，“看看这家公司获得了多少资金”的故事只是前两个故事的变体，具体取决于资金总额。

新应用程序的保留率达到 40-50% 就非常不错了。我认为没有理由怀疑扎克伯格的说法，即 Threads 的保留率高于他们的预期。您所需要做的就是使用Threads 来查看它的蓬勃发展。它是否走上了长期成功的道路？我不明白怎么会有人这么早就这么说，但看起来确实更有可能。我们甚至还没有提到 Threads 尚未在整个欧盟可用的事实。

一个有趣的数据点来自 Google 的 Play 商店，其中“社交”类别中排名靠前的免费应用程序如下所示，正如我在东部时间晚上 8 点所写的那样：

  1. 抖音
  2. Instagram
  3. Facebook
  4. 线程数
  5. X
  6. 红迪网
  7. 脸书精简版
  8. 比戈现场
  9. 文本免费
  10. 大量的鱼约会应用程序

今晚早些时候，同一个列表中的应用程序 4-7 是 Threads、X、Reddit 和 Facebook Lite，但顺序不同。我认为这意味着前 3 个是大 3，接下来的 4 个在第二层中彼此接近。然后奇怪的应用程序就会减少。

苹果应用商店中的“社交网络”类别有很大不同，因为许多应用程序并不属于“社交网络”类别。在 App Store 中，该类别前 5 名分别是 WhatsApp、Facebook、Telegram、Threads 和 Facebook Messenger；在 Android 上，WhatsApp、Messenger、Telegram（和 Snapchat！）都属于“通信”类别。 Instagram 和 Snapchat 属于“照片和视频”类别。 X，就像它被命名为 Twitter 时一样，属于“新闻”类别，它看起来比实际更受欢迎。

以下是这些应用程序在 App Store 中所有应用程序中的排名：

5. 抖音
6. WhatsApp
9.Instagram
13.脸书
16. 电报
18. 快照
21. 线程
31. 信使
35. X

他们使用不同的排名公式（并且都对公式保密，以阻止对排名进行游戏的企图），但 App Store 和 Play Store 的 Threads 都领先于 X。你绝对想不到，从本周末的“Threads 是一个半身像”来看， ” 头条新闻。

entry.title: [赞助商] Warp——重新构想你的终端
Meta 线程启动内部
entry.content:
内奥米·尼克斯和威尔·奥雷穆斯为《华盛顿邮报》报道：

在扎克伯格的授权下，莫塞里冒着巨大的风险，组建了一支不到 60 人的精干、由工程师组成的团队，以极快的时间表拼凑出一款简单的应用程序，这更像是一家初创企业，而不是一家根深蒂固的科技巨头。本周，在 Meta 公布强劲收益后，扎克伯格向投资者发表讲话，称 Threads 证明了他的“ 效率之年”，在这一年中，他裁掉了数万个工作岗位，以建立更敏捷的团队，以快速交付产品。

根据匿名讨论内部事务的现任和前任员工的说法，Threads 是由这么小的一个团体在如此短的时间内创建的，这在 Meta 内部已经成为一个奇迹。邮报。许多人认为它的快速崛起提醒人们，执行良好的产品发布可能不需要一家拥有约 66,000 名员工的公司已经习惯的所有官僚主义装饰。

“快速执行。没什么特别的，”一位用户在匿名工作场所应用程序 Blind 上写道。 “我们的大多数IC （个人贡献者）都可以做扎实的工程，但不幸的是受到束缚。”

令我感到惊讶的是，任何有任何经验的人都会对一支规模较小的才华横溢的团队如此高效表示惊讶。 （我说“ish”是因为 50-60 人并不算少。） 弗雷德·布鲁克斯 (Fred Brooks) 的《人月神话》不知何故同时闻名，但又被广泛忽视。更大的团队可能会推迟 Threads，而不是加速其发布。一个更大的团队可能注定该项目会失败。

为了让事情继续进行，Threads 团队放弃了棘手的决定，并避开了困难的功能，包括私人消息以及搜索内容或查看您不关注的人的提要的功能。该公司还选择不在欧盟推出，监管机构正准备明年执行新规则，要求科技公司向监管机构提供有关其算法的更多信息。

“你先做简单的事情，”莫塞里说。 “我认为这也有助于缩小范围，因为经常发生的情况是范围蔓延，你想要添加所有这些东西，因为它们都很棒。”

找出一些好的东西，即使它缺少明显的重要功能，然后开始迭代。这就是食谱。不过，我很好奇 Threads 上的私人消息会发生什么故事——又一个新的消息孤岛，还是与 Instagram 相关的东西？不管是什么，我当然希望它使用E2EE。

（ 众所周知，Twitter DM 不使用 E2EE，因此 Twitter 上发送的每一条表面上的私人消息都可以被具有访问权限的 Twitter 员工读取，因此可能会因错误或恶意而暴露给公众。Mastodon 也是如此，它提供“仅提及的人”消息传递，在我看来，这一功能不应该存在，因为它造成了隐私的错觉。根本不提供私人消息传递比在没有 E2EE 的情况下提供它更好。）

★

entry.title: 研究表明 Facebook 的算法具有“影响力”，但不一定会改变人们的信念
entry.content:
Mike Isaac 和 Sheera Frenkel 上周为《纽约时报》报道：

来自德克萨斯大学、纽约大学、普林斯顿大学等机构的研究人员在论文中发现，删除社交平台算法的一些关键功能对人们的政治信仰“没有可衡量的影响”。研究人员表示，在 Facebook 算法的一项实验中，当人们转发帖子的能力被取消时，他们对政治新闻的了解就会下降。

与此同时， 另一项研究表明，Facebook 和 Instagram 上的政治新闻消费因意识形态而高度隔离。研究发现，2020 年大选期间，超过 97% 的新闻报道链接被应用程序上的事实核查人员评为虚假，吸引的保守派读者多于自由派读者。 [...] 研究人员表示，尽管如此，Facebook 用户阅读的虚假新闻文章的比例与查看的所有新闻文章相比仍然较低。

虚假新闻文章总体数量较低，但被视为虚假的文章被保守派大量阅读。这并不奇怪，但对我来说，这触及了争议的核心。一种假设的社交媒体算法可以完美准确地宣传真实故事并压制虚假故事，但保守派将指责这种算法对保守派有偏见，因为保守派容易被虚假故事所吸引。

《华尔街日报》的 Jeff Horwitz 报道（ News+ 链接）在 Facebook 上夸大了这些新研究在多大程度上免除了其平台的影响力：

负责《科学》研究结果传播的梅根·费兰 (Meagan Phelan) 表示，本周早些时候，《科学》杂志警告 Meta，它将公开质疑一项主张，即已发表的研究应该被解读为在很大程度上免除了 Meta 在社会分歧中所扮演的重要角色。

根据她与《华尔街日报》分享的消息摘录，费兰周一对 Meta 的通讯团队表示：“研究结果表明，Meta 算法是导致人们分裂的重要因素。”她补充说，其中一项研究发现，“与自由派相比，政治保守派用户的新闻来源更加孤立，部分是由算法过程驱动的，在 Facebook 的页面和群组上尤其明显。”

entry.title: Counterpoint 称美国智能手机销量下降，但主要是 Android 手机销量下降
entry.content:
马修·奥尔夫（Matthew Orf）为 Counterpoint Research 撰文：

根据 Counterpoint Research 的市场监测数据，2023 年第二季度美国智能手机出货量同比下降 24%。这是连续第三个季度同比下降。三星、摩托罗拉和TCL阿尔卡特等Android品牌的出货量下降幅度最大，而苹果的出货量则更具弹性。因此，苹果的出货量份额同比有所增加。

Android 智能手机出货量同比下降 38%，而苹果智能手机出货量同比下降 6%。

根据 Counterpoint 的数据，三星的销量与 Android 的整体销量完全一致，总体下降了 37%。你可能会认为他们销售的所有可折叠产品会上涨，而不是下跌。另一个有趣的消息：Counterpoint 声称 Google Pixel 销量同比增长 48%。如果这是真的，也许 Pixels 终于开始受到关注了？我必须赞扬谷歌的顽强坚持。

苹果在 Counterpoint 统计中的出货量份额已连续 4 个季度超过 50%。

entry.summary: 其他篮球运动员可以打得和迈克尔·乔丹一样好，但他们只是不愿意这样做。
entry.content:
ZDNet 本周的实际标题是：“ 苹果很快就需要一款可折叠 iPhone，否则 iPhone 将不值得购买”。菲利普·伯尔尼写道：

自从我买了 iPhone 14 Pro 以来，更酷的手机出现了，而且都是可折叠手机。如果苹果不能很快推出可折叠 iPhone，那么人们就不会再兴奋了，而且苹果的手机也很难在新的创新中脱颖而出。

可折叠设备的前景——折叠后可放入口袋，展开时平板电脑大小——的前景是显而易见的。我经常举起《西部世界》中的超薄可折叠平板电脑作为对未来的憧憬。但最关键的形容词是“超薄”。双倍厚度的可折叠设备在我看来是一个利基市场，而今天的可折叠设备不仅是双倍厚度，而且价格是双倍的。三星新推出的 Fold 5 手机引发了伯尔尼的标题党专栏，起价为 1,800 美元，不提供防尘功能，仅提供防水功能。

十年前，苹果公司在手机领域起步较晚。当时我们称它们为“平板手机”；我们现在称它们为“电话”。那些大型安卓手机卖得很好。在 2013 年规划公司 2014 年战略的演示文稿中（该战略在苹果诉三星诉讼中公开），苹果公司自己这样描述了这种情况：“ 消费者想要我们没有的东西。” （第一款大屏幕 iPhone iPhone 6 Plus 于 2014 年 9 月发布。）

我敢打赌，今年苹果公司不会有关于可折叠产品的“消费者想要我们没有的东西”的幻灯片。

以下是 Counterpoint 的一份报告，他们似乎对未来几年的可折叠设备相当乐观：

2022年，可折叠手机类别占据全球智能手机出货量的1.1%，但在超高端市场占据重要地位，约占800美元以上智能手机出货量的7%。根据Counterpoint Research《2022年第三季度全球可折叠智能手机市场预测》，预计2023年全球可折叠智能手机市场将达到2270万部。

手机总数的 1% 和 800 美元以上手机的 7% 并不是什么大数字，而且我发现 7% 的数字非常令人难以置信。以下是另一家公司 Canalys 的最新报告，该报告列出了 2023 年第一季度全球 15 款 500 美元以上最畅销手机。榜单上唯一的可折叠手机是三星 Galaxy Z Flip4，排名第十。名单上没有一款书本式可折叠手机，Z Flip4 仅领先 iPhone SE 一点点。

可折叠设备——书本式、翻盖式或两者兼而有之——很可能成为一种事物，但它们还不是一种事物，因为技术还没有达到使它们引人注目的程度。 （包括简单地使其防尘。）

伯尔尼继续说道：

Galaxy S23 Ultra 是我最喜欢的手机，在我们的最佳手机列表中名列前茅，因为它具备一切功能，甚至更多。它实际上是一台装在手机里的笔记本电脑。苹果不是为了填充。苹果讲究的是精致。

做得比一切都多是一项相当大的成就。我百分百惊讶的是我没有听到更多关于此事的消息。

苹果，我有好消息。 iPhone已经足够精致了。它的精益求精远远超出了其他制造商所希望达到的水平。其他手机制造商可以制造出同样注重细节的手机，但他们只是不愿意这样做。这是不值得付出努力或成本的。

其他篮球运动员可以打得和迈克尔·乔丹一样好，但他们只是不愿意这样做。这是不值得付出成本或努力的。

entry.title: 埃丝特·克劳福德 (Esther Crawford) 在 Twitter 上，查尔斯·福斯特·马斯克 (Charles Foster Musk) 接管之前和之后
entry.content:
埃丝特·克劳福德（Esther Crawford）（之前在这里提到过，她在推特上吹嘘自己在工作中睡觉是为了赶上不必要的最后期限），写了一篇精彩的文章，讲述了她在公司的经历，包括马斯克收购前后的情况。

虽然我对埃隆了解不多，但我持谨慎乐观的态度——我认为他是建立了特斯拉和 SpaceX 等令人难以置信且持久的公司的人，所以也许他的私人所有权可以改变现状，为公司注入新的活力。

克劳福德在公司内部，而我则远离公司，但这正是我对马斯克领导下的 Twitter 持乐观态度的原因。 Twitter 几年前（也许是十年前）就已经僵化了，需要对整个系统进行彻底的改组，无论是公司文化还是产品。虽然我认为马斯克领导下的 Twitter 现在情况要糟糕得多，但他绝对确实改变了一切，如今类似 Twitter 的服务的整体状况比以前要好得多。在马斯克收购 Twitter 之前，Mastodon 是无关紧要的。否则，11 月之后的增长就不会出现。我现在乐观地看好 Threads，而且我认为，如果不是马斯克收购并摧毁了 Twitter，Threads 甚至不会存在。

我认为这是一个敏锐的洞察力：

埃隆在解决基于物理的难题方面拥有非凡的天赋，但促进人与人之间的联系和沟通的产品需要不同类型的社交情感智能。

另一种思考这个问题的方式（我抄袭了 Ben Thompson 本周在Dithering上所说的话）并不是马斯克缺乏同理心，而只是软件本身的本质。不变的物理定律以不适用于软件的方式抵制马斯克的不合理要求。他似乎不听不同意他观点的人的意见，但当物理学不同意时他必须倾听。 （今天早些时候关于特斯拉伪造续航里程估计的故事纯粹是由软件决定的。）

软件比硬件需要更多的创造性纪律，因为如此多的纪律已经融入到创建硬件的本质中。硬件向人们灌输纪律；人们必须向软件灌输纪律。

如果我没有注意到，在所有这一切中，还有一个对任何取得成功的人的警示故事，那就是我的失职——那就是，你爬得越高，你的世界就会变得越小。这是一个奇怪的悖论，但最富有和最有权势的人也是最孤立的人。

我发现自己经常看着埃隆，看到一个看起来很孤独的人，因为他的时间和精力完全投入到工作中，这不是我想要的生活模式。

查尔斯·福斯特·马斯克 (Charles Foster Musk) 嘟哝着“X”而不是“Rosebud”。

entry.content:
Steve Stecklow 和 Norihiko Shirouzu，路透社报道：

特斯拉几年前就开始通过操纵其里程估算软件来夸大其车辆的潜在行驶距离。据一位熟悉该软件早期设计的人士透露，大约十年前，出于营销目的，该公司决定为其测距仪编写算法，向驾驶员显示充满电池后可以行驶的距离的“乐观”预测。其仪表板读数。

这位人士表示，然后，当电池电量低于最大电量的 50% 时，该算法将为驾驶员显示更真实的剩余行驶里程预测。消息人士称，为了防止驾驶员因预计行驶里程开始更快下降而陷入困境，特斯拉设计了“安全缓冲区”，即使在仪表板读数显示电池电量耗尽后，也可以增加约 15 英里（24 公里）的行驶里程。

这位人士表示，提出乐观范围估计的指令来自特斯拉首席执行官埃隆·马斯克(Elon Musk)。 “埃隆希望在充满电后显示出良好的续航里程数，”该人士说道，并补充道：“当你从停车场购买一辆汽车时，看到续航里程为 350 英里、400 英里，这会让你感觉很好。”

这不是“每个人都这样做”的情况：

汽车网站 Edmunds.com 的车辆测试总监 Jonathan Elfalan 在对特斯拉以及福特、通用汽车、现代和保时捷等其他主要汽车制造商的车辆进行了广泛检查后，得出了与 Pannone 类似的结论。该网站于 2021 年 2 月报道，Edmunds 测试的所有五款特斯拉车型均未能达到其宣传的续航里程。其他制造商的其他 10 款车型中，除了一款之外，其他车型均超出了其宣传的续航里程。

伊利诺伊州州长 JB Pritzker 在西北大学毕业典礼上的演讲片段对我来说非常真实。随着年龄的增长，我的想法也越来越遵循同样的思路。整个剪辑值得一看，但重点是：

发现白痴的最好方法是什么？寻找残忍的人。当我们看到某人长得不像我们、听起来不像我们、行为不像我们、爱不像我们、生活不像我们时，几乎每个人的第一个想法要么源于恐惧，要么源于判断，或两者兼而有之。这就是进化。作为一个物种，我们通过对不熟悉的事物保持怀疑而生存下来。

为了变得友善，我们必须关闭动物本能，迫使我们的大脑走上不同的道路。同理心和同情心是进化的存在状态。它们需要心理能力来超越我们最原始的冲动。我来这里是想告诉你们，当一个人在这个世界上的道路上充满了残酷行为时，他们就没有通过先进社会的第一次考验。他们从不强迫自己的动物大脑进化超越其第一本能。他们从未建立新的心理途径来克服自己本能的恐惧。因此，他们的思维和解决问题的能力将缺乏最善良的人所拥有的想象力和创造力。

在我多年的政界和商界生涯中，我发现一件事是普遍正确的：房间里最善良的人往往是最聪明的。

entry.title: 疫苗问世后，共和党各县的新冠死亡率更高
entry.content:
Jacob Wallace、Paul Goldsmith-Pinkham 和 Jason L. Schwartz 在《JAMA Internal Medicine》上发表的一篇论文《佛罗里达州和俄亥俄州共和党和民主党登记选民在 COVID-19 大流行期间的死亡率过高》中表示：

2018年1月1日至2021年12月31日期间，俄亥俄州和佛罗里达州的研究样本中有538,159人死亡年龄为25岁或以上。死亡中位年龄为 78 岁（IQR，71-89 岁）。总体而言，共和党选民的超额死亡率比民主党选民的超额死亡率高出 2.8 个百分点，即 15%（95% 预测区间 [PI]，1.6-3.7 个百分点）。 2021 年 5 月 1 日之后，当所有成年人都能接种疫苗后，共和党和民主党选民之间的超额死亡率差距从 -0.9 个百分点（95% PI，-2.5 至 0.3 个百分点）扩大到 7.7 个百分点（95% PI） ，6.0-9.3个百分点）在调整后的分析中；共和党选民的超额死亡率比民主党选民的超额死亡率高出43%。在疫苗接种率较低的县，共和党和民主党选民之间的超额死亡率差距更大，这一差距主要体现在居住在俄亥俄州的选民中。

这项研究强烈表明，与新冠病毒死亡率相关的唯一因素是疫苗接种。此外，新冠肺炎是一种主要导致老年人死亡的疾病——这项研究中的超额死亡率全部发生在 75 岁及以上的人群中。即使在 65-74 岁的人群中，超额死亡率也有所下降。在疫苗问世之前，倾向共和党和倾向民主党的县之间的所有其他政策差异并未导致死亡率出现差异。

我不知道如何解释只有俄亥俄州而非佛罗里达州出现超额死亡率这一事实。这项研究本身似乎并没有为这种差异提供假设。也许是天气？俄亥俄州的老年人在室内呆的时间更多，而那里的新冠病毒传播可能性更大？

（通过政治专线。）

entry.content:
Ryan Mac 和 Tiffany Hsu，《纽约时报》报道：

这位去年收购了 Twitter 的科技亿万富翁在其网站上将社交平台重新命名为 X.com，并开始用拉丁字母表第 24 个字母的程式化版本取代鸟标志。据《纽约时报》看到的照片显示，在 Twitter 位于旧金山的总部内，自助餐厅里投射了 X 标志，而会议室也被重新命名为带有 X 的单词，包括“eXposure”、“eXult”和“s3Xy”。

这就是为什么特斯拉的车辆型号为 S、3、X 和 Y，并在公司网站上按此顺序列出。它就像联邦快递标志中的箭头，但适用于 12 岁的男孩。

马斯克早就表示他可能会更名，但他在周日早些时候的一条推文中加快了这一进程，他宣称“很快我们将告别 Twitter 品牌，并逐渐告别所有鸟类。”他曾表示，希望将 Twitter 打造成一款名为 X 的“一切应用程序”，不仅涵盖社交网络，还涵盖银行和购物。

周一早些时候，马斯克还分享了一张 Twitter 旧金山办公楼上投影的巨型 X 的照片，并配文：“今晚是我们的总部。”

我讨厌*说“我早就告诉过你了”，但我早在 5 月 1 日就预测到了这一确切的名称变更。正如我在几周后重申这一预测时所写的：

事实上，他现在主要将其称为“这个平台”，这让我认为他会尽快将其重命名为“X”。不过，在我看来，抛弃 Twitter 品牌名称似乎很疯狂，所以也许“X”对于 Twitter 来说就像“Meta”对于 Facebook 和“Alphabet”对于 Google 一样。但同时：马斯克也做了一些疯狂的事情。扔掉整个 Twitter 品牌不会比他一开始就买下它那么疯狂。

《泰晤士报》的这篇文章引用了一位品牌专家的话说，显而易见的是，品牌名称的动词非常罕见，而且非常有价值。当人们在 Twitter 上发帖时，他们就是在发推文。他们发的推文就是推文。每个人，甚至是从未使用过 Twitter 的人，都知道tweet 的含义。现在马斯克认为它们会被称为“x”？

尽管事实上马斯克几个月来显然一直在朝着更名的方向努力——如果不是从他提议购买该公司之前开始的话——这一转变完全是（但可以预见的）草率。马斯克声称是“临时”的新徽标只是Unicode 字符“𝕏” （U+1D54F，数学双连大写 X ）。该公司今天试图更换旧金山总部的标牌，但由于对该公司是否拥有工作许可证感到困惑，工作被迫停止，标牌仅被部分拆除。 iOS和Android应用程序都没有更新，甚至该公司的网站上几乎到处都写着“Twitter”。

* 我所说的“恨”当然是指“爱” ，整个周末我都在令人难以忍受地炫耀我的“Being Right Point™”（正确点™）。

亲爱的地球上每一个曾经输入过文字的人，

我知道这只是一个轻松的问候，但让“每个人”看到 Office 默认字体的并不是文本的输入，而是文本的阅读。除了 Excel 之外，我从未经常使用过任何 Office 应用程序，那是 20 多年前的事了。但无论您个人是否使用 Office，都不可能不遇到使用 Office 创建的文档。因此，微软的排版选择影响着我们所有人。 （例如，我从未在 Arial 中设置过任何内容，但由于它的普遍存在，它几乎每天都会令人烦恼。）

15 年来，我们心爱的 Calibri 一直是 Microsoft 的默认字体和办公通信的皇冠守护者，但如您所知，我们的关系已经自然结束。我们改变了。我们每天使用的技术已经发生了变化。因此，我们开始寻找适合更高分辨率屏幕的完美字体。字体需要具有清晰度、均匀性，并且适合显示类型。有时令人兴奋，但也令人生畏。如何替换 Calibri？您如何找到一种真正的字体可以取代它作为正确的默认字体？

正如我们之前分享的，微软委托使用了五种新字体：Bierstadt、Grandview、Seaford、Skeena 和 Tenorite。我们希望其中一种能够成为 Microsoft 365 的下一个默认字体。所有这些字体都已添加到下拉字体选择器中。从那时起，当您有机会使用它们时，我们听取了您热情的反馈，并选择了最能引起共鸣的一个，那就是比尔施塔特。但随着警卫的变化，名字也发生了变化。比尔施塔特现在被称为阿普托斯。

我不知道微软是否真的根据客户反馈选择了 Aptos（née Bierstadt），但无论如何，它都说明了该公司的很多情况。 有品味的公司不会通过调查来进行设计。 （我的猜测是，他们一派胡言，可能从一开始就知道他们会选择阿普托斯/比尔施塔特，这是显而易见的选择。“调查”，这样的，似乎只是阅读人们的回复在推特上。）

我觉得整个事情很奇怪的是微软仍然没有真正展示任何这些新字体。他们已经提供了它们的一瞥，但主要是大显示尺寸，而不是文本尺寸，而这正是它们在 Office 文档上下文中真正重要的地方。我不是唯一一个对此感到好奇的人。

因此，我亲自动手，为微软的五种新字体（以及 Calibri）中的每一种创建了基本样本。大写和小写的 A–Z、0–9 以及最常见的标点符号。然后是11点处的一段示例文本。亲爱的读者，您真的欠我这个，因为我必须使用 Web 应用程序版本的 Word，通过 Microsoft 365 2来生成这些 PDF。用残酷和令人沮丧来形容这个软件是轻描淡写的。谨此附上 PDF 样本和我的简短评论：

  • Aptos — 由Steve Matteson设计。我不知道为什么 Microsoft 声称 Calibri需要以某种方式替换为默认字体，只是因为它已经有 15 年历史了。一个好的默认字体即使不能经受住生命的考验，也应该能经受几十年时间的考验。 3 But if Microsoft feels the need to chase fleeting fashion rather than timeless style, Aptos is the trendiest of the bunch: grotesque sans serifs are having a moment. Aptos is by no means a rip-off of Apple's San Francisco , but it is, by far, the most San-Francisco-esque of any of these typefaces. Noteworthy characters: J (stunted and ugly), Q (small tail), R (inspired by Univers ?), g (double-story, reminiscent of Franklin Gothic 's), and the numeral 1 (curved hat, à la , of all fonts, Arial). But the most distinctive character is the lowercase L, which has a curve to differentiate it from the uppercase i and numeral 1.

  • Grandview — Designer Aaron Bell admits Grandview was largely inspired by DIN, and it certainly looks like it. Far too mechanical to serve as the default font. For chrissake look at those quotation marks and apostrophes.

  • Seaford — Designed by Tobias Frere-Jones, Nina Stössinger, and Fred Shallcrass . Seaford strikes me as the only other font in the bunch that might conceivably have been chosen as the new default. If Microsoft had better (any?) taste, they would have chosen Seaford. Seaford strikes my eye as most similar to Martin Majoor's rightfully renowned and beloved Scala Sans , with — maybe — a wee dose of influence from, of all typefaces, Frere-Jones's ex-partner Jonathan Hoefler's aptly-named Ideal Sans . 4

  • Skeena — Designed by John Hudson and Paul Hanslow . Looks like it came off a clip art CD circa 1995.

  • Tenorite — Designed by Erin McLaughlin and Wei Huang . Admittedly inspired by Adrian Frutiger's hall-of-fame typeface Avenir , and looks like it. Too friendly, bordering on childish (see the single-story lowercase “a”), to serve as the default for Office.

  • Calibri — Designed by Lucas de Groot . It's not my bag, personally, 5 but Calibri is both a very good sans serif and a fine default for Office. There's no reason Microsoft couldn't have stuck with Calibri for decades to come.

Here's a zip archive of all 6 specimens , if you'd prefer to download them all.

Original Postscript

The kerning is rather awful in all of these PDF specimens, at times jarringly so. I suspect, or at least hope, the problem is with the web version of Word (which I presume has its own text rendering engine), not the fonts themselves. Look, for example, at the words milliner and Uncle (which looks like “Unde” in some of them) in the sample text. If these fonts were available for download, I'd have typeset the specimens using better software, but they're not, so I can't. I suppose I could fish out the web fonts used by Microsoft 365, but this whole endeavor has consumed enough of my time as it is.

New Postscript, Updated 22 July

The kerning problem with the original PDFs I produced was indeed, ultimately, caused by the fact that I was using the web version of Microsoft Word. Friend of the show Glenn Fleishman used the native Mac version of Word to produce new PDFs from my Word documents, and the kerning problems are gone. All of the above links now go the updated PDFs. (And of course Glenn, of all people, cared enough to lend a hand.) If you're curious, and I suppose I would be if I were you, here's an archive of the original PDFs with the perverse kerning.

  1. Why is the Microsoft Design blog hosted at Medium, rather than at Microsoft's own website, like the company's main blog ? ↩︎

  2. Which I have access to by way of my team account for Dithering . You'll never guess which of us set that up. ↩︎︎

  3. Apple's default font (as seen today in apps like Pages, Numbers, and TextEdit, and in bygone times in apps like MacWrite and SimpleText) has been nearly unchanged since 1991 or so , switching only from Helvetica to its superior expanded sibling Helvetica Neue . Prior to Helvetica, the default font was Geneva , Susan Kare 's pixel font homage to Helvetica. No one is going to make a movie about Aptos. ↩︎︎

  4. Ideal Sans should be familiar to those of you who remember Vesper , which speaks to my deep and abiding affinity for it. ↩︎︎

  5. De Groot's Consolas , which he designed as a fixed-width counterpart to Calibri, is my most-used monospaced font. This entire article, right down to this footnote, was drafted using Consolas in BBEdit. ↩︎︎

Apple Tries to Explain to UK Legislators That You Can't Add Back Doors to Secure Protocols
entry.content:
Zoe Kleinman, reporting for BBC News:

Apple says it will remove services such as FaceTime and iMessage from the UK rather than weaken security if new proposals are made law and acted upon.

The government is seeking to update the Investigatory Powers Act (IPA) 2016. It wants messaging services to clear security features with the Home Office before releasing them to customers. The act lets the Home Office demand security features are disabled, without telling the public. Under the update, this would have to be immediate. [...]

WhatsApp and Signal are among the platforms to have opposed a clause in the Online Safety Bill allowing the communications regulator to require companies to install technology to scan for child-abuse material in encrypted messaging apps and other services. They will not comply with it, they say, with Signal threatening to “walk” from the UK.

The BBC headline here is fair: “Apple Slams UK Surveillance-Bill Proposals”. Techmeme's rewrite of the headline is not: “Apple Threatens to Remove Services Like FaceTime and iMessage From the UK Rather Than Weaken Their Security Under a Proposed Investigatory Powers Act Amendment”. Usually this works the other way around — Techmeme typically rewrites headlines to add clarity and omit clickbait-yness. But Apple (and Signal, and WhatsApp) aren't making threats here. They're patiently explaining that E2EE messaging platforms cannot comply with what the UK wants to demand. It'd be like trying to comply with a law that declares 1 + 1 = 3.

The UK legislators pushing this believe, wrongly, that it must be possible for these messaging platforms to add “good guys only” back doors. That if they pass this law, the result will be that the nerds who work at these companies will be forced to figure out a way to comply. What will actually happen is that these companies will be forced to pull the services from UK, because they can't comply, unless they scrap their current end-to-end encryption and replace it — worldwide — with something insecure, which they aren't going to do.

The UK, of course, is no longer part of the EU, but the unintended consequences are similar: the intention of the EU's Digital Markets Act (well, one intention among many) is to force big social networks to collect data in ways that are more respectful of users' privacy. The actual result is that Threads launched everywhere else in the world but the EU. The intention of the UK's proposed update to the IPA is to force messaging platforms to make profound technical changes that would allow law enforcement to snoop on messages; the actual result, if it goes into effect, will be to force those messaging platforms out of the UK.

And while it's Apple and iMessage/FaceTime that are getting the headlines today, it's WhatsApp that's the big player in the UK , with 75 percent of adult Britons using it monthly. It's hard to overstate how much outrage these legislators are poised to bring upon themselves if they effectively ban WhatsApp. (The legislators themselves surely all depend upon it.)

★

entry.title: Facebook Releases Llama 2 Under an 'Open for Everyone Other Than Really Large Rivals' License
entry.content:
Facebook:

We're now ready to open source the next version of Llama 2 and are making it available free of charge for research and commercial use . We're including model weights and starting code for the pretrained model and conversational fine-tuned versions too. As Satya Nadella announced on stage at Microsoft Inspire, we're taking our partnership to the next level with Microsoft as our preferred partner for Llama 2 and expanding our efforts in generative AI. Starting today, Llama 2 is available in the Azure AI model catalog, enabling developers using Microsoft Azure to build with it and leverage their cloud-native tools for content filtering and safety features. It is also optimized to run locally on Windows, giving developers a seamless workflow as they bring generative AI experiences to customers across different platforms. Llama 2 is available through Amazon Web Services (AWS), Hugging Face, and other providers too.

First, this is yet another sign that OpenAI has no moat around LLM AI technology . Second, I'm glad to see Facebook drop their awkward “LLaMA” letter-casing style. Third, there's a notable restriction in Llama 2's license :

2. Additional Commercial Terms. If, on the Llama 2 version release date, the monthly active users of the products or services made available by or for Licensee, or Licensee's affiliates, is greater than 700 million monthly active users in the preceding calendar month, you must request a license from Meta, which Meta may grant to you in its sole discretion, and you are not authorized to exercise any of the rights under this Agreement unless or until Meta otherwise expressly grants you such rights.

700 million seems oddly specific. Obviously the other companies in the Big Five exceed that number (Apple, Google, Amazon, Microsoft), but who else? Ben Thompson, in today's subscriber-only Stratechery update (and — spoiler — tomorrow's episode of Dithering) notes:

Probably the closest company to that 700 million monthly active user (MAU) figure is Snap, which said it passed 750 million MAUs earlier this year . Obviously all of the other big consumer tech companies have more than 700 million MAUs, as well as other services like Telegram, which just surpassed 800 million MAUs .

Good news for Elon Musk, though: Twitter is free to use it .

entry.title: Wayne Ma: Display Manufacturing Problems Might Lead to Shortages of iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max
entry.content:
Wayne Ma, reporting for The Information (paywalled):

The iPhone 15 Pro, internally codenamed D83, and Pro Max, codenamed D84, are now in a manufacturing stage known as risk ramp in which Foxconn Technology, which does final assembly of the phones, makes hundreds of thousands of units of the device to test how reliably they can build the product without defects. Apple traditionally moves to mass production, where it begins making millions of iPhone units, in August. The phones typically start to ship to customers in late September.

One person with direct knowledge said the LG-made displays have failed reliability tests after it goes through a new process known as low injection pressure overmolding or LIPO. The process involves Apple fusing the display into its metal shell prior to assembly. Apple is repeatedly tweaking the design of LG's display so that it can pass the tests.

However, Apple still can use displays made by its leading supplier Samsung, ensuring that it can continue to assemble a significant amount of units.

What going legit was to Michael Corleone, breaking free of dependence upon Samsung is to Tim Cook: “ Just when I thought I was out, they pull me back in .”

entry.title: Kevin Mitnick Dies From Pancreatic Cancer at 59
entry.content:
Tragic news from King David Memorial Chapel and Cemetery in Las Vegas:

Kevin David Mitnick, 59, died peacefully on Sunday, July 16, 2023, after valiantly battling pancreatic cancer for more than a year. Kevin is survived by his beloved wife, Kimberley Mitnick, who remained by his side throughout their 14-month ordeal. Kimberley is pregnant with their first child. Kevin was ecstatic about this new chapter in his and Kimberley's life together, which has now been sadly cut short.

All cancers can go fuck themselves, but man, pancreatic cancer has taken so many people of late: Alex Trebek, Pixar animator Ralph Eggleston , Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and of course Steve Jobs. Also: Jef Raskin and Randy Pausch (“ The Last Lecture ” professor).

Just brutal to hear that Mitnick's wife is pregnant.

Kevin emerged from his final prison term, which he deemed a “vacation”, in January 2000. He was a changed individual, and began constructing a new career, as a White Hat hacker and security consultant. He became a highly sought-after global public speaker, a writer, and established the successful Mitnick Security Consulting. In November 2011, he became the Chief Hacking Officer and part owner of security awareness training company KnowBe4, founded by close friend and business partner Stu Sjouwerman.

Kevin attracted attention and support from unlikely sources. The bus driver who saw young Kevin memorize the bus schedules, punch cards and punch tool systems so he could ride the buses all day for free testified as a character witness for Kevin during his federal trial. The federal prosecutor offered his testimony that Kevin never tried to take one dime from any of his “victims”. The probation officer assigned to monitor Kevin after prison gave Kevin permission to write his first book on a laptop when he was not yet supposed to have access to computers. Shawn Nunley, the star witness in the FBI's case against Kevin, became so disillusioned with the government's treatment of Kevin that he contacted Kevin's defense team, helped garner Kevin's release, and became one of Kevin's dearest friends. Kevin had an irresistible way of converting foes to friends and keeping them as friends forever.

Mitnick was technically gifted, but his greatest hacking skill was social engineering.

★

entry.summary: Once you view Bloomberg's original reporting through this prism — that most of their original reporting is delivered with the goal of moving the stock prices of the companies they're reporting on, for the purpose of proving the value of a Bloomberg Terminal's hefty subscription fee to day-trading gamblers — a lot of their seemingly inexplicable stylistic quirks don't seem so inexplicable any more.
entry.content:
Mark Gurman, reporting for Bloomberg, “ Apple Tests 'Apple GPT,' Develops Generative AI Tools to Catch OpenAI ”:

The iPhone maker has built its own framework to create large language models — the AI-based systems at the heart of new offerings like ChatGPT and Google's Bard — according to people with knowledge of the efforts. With that foundation, known as “Ajax”, Apple also has created a chatbot service that some engineers call “Apple GPT”.

In recent months, the AI push has become a major effort for Apple, with several teams collaborating on the project, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the matter is private. The work includes trying to address potential privacy concerns related to the technology.

It's not surprising that Apple has a project like this underway. It would be rather shocking if they didn't. And it shouldn't be surprising that Apple is a latecomer to shipping software that exposes AI chatbot-type features. Apple is seldom first to adopt new technology, especially something with the privacy ramifications of AI chat.

I was banging this drum before WWDC, but one app that needs this sort of functionality is Xcode. Xcode is the only major developer IDE I'm aware of that doesn't offer AI code generation and analysis. I've seen some demos from readers who use Microsoft's VS Code and they're amazing.

Next paragraph:

Apple shares gained as much as 2.3% to a record high of $198.23 after Bloomberg reported on the AI effort Wednesday, rebounding from earlier losses. Microsoft Corp., OpenAI's partner and main backer, slipped about 1% on the news.

If you ever notice, Bloomberg news stories always contain updates like this. It's an obsession unique to Bloomberg. My understanding is that this decade-old Business Insider story remains true : Bloomberg reporters are evaluated and receive bonuses tied to reporting market-moving news. They're incentivized financially to make mountains out of molehills, and craters out of divots, to maximize the immediate effect of their reporting on stock prices. And Bloomberg appends these stock price movements right there in their reports, to drive home the notion that Bloomberg publishes market-moving news, so maybe you too should spend over $2,000 per month on a Bloomberg Terminal so that you can receive news reports from Bloomberg minutes before the general public, and buy, sell, and short stocks based on that news. No other news organization I'm aware of has an incentive system like this for reporters — but no other news organization has a business like the Bloomberg Terminal.

Here's the graph of Apple's share price today . Gurman's report was published at 12:03pm, and boom, Apple's stock price jumped at exactly 12:04pm. It then mostly came back down to where it was, presumably after everyone realized there really wasn't any news here other than the fact that Apple is working on something we all presumed they were working on. Apple's stock finished up 0.7 percent for the day.

Microsoft's stock graph for today doesn't show as dramatic a downward spike as Apple's jump, but they were trading at $359.35 at 12:01, and dropped to $356.84 at exactly 12:04, one minute after Gurman's report hit Bloomberg Terminals. The “ this is bad news for Microsoft ” line of thinking, presumably, is that if OpenAI has a long-term moat around LLM AI technology, Microsoft is likely to acquire them or otherwise maintain their position as an exclusive partner, and Apple might eventually need to pay through the nose to license OpenAI/Microsoft technology. But if there is no moat , and even Apple is developing its own LLM systems, then maybe Microsoft's partnership with OpenAI isn't worth much long-term.

Apple's brief 2.7 percent jump and Microsoft's smaller but still-significant drop, both at 12:04pm, were clearly caused by Gurman's report. Bloomberg Terminal subscribers get such reports before anyone else. (Bloomberg employees, of course, know such information before it's published, but I'm sure never do anything untoward with it.) Once you view Bloomberg's original reporting through this prism — that most of their original reporting is delivered with the goal of moving the stock prices of the companies they're reporting on, for the purpose of proving the value of a Bloomberg Terminal's hefty subscription fee 1 to day-trading gamblers — a lot of their seemingly inexplicable stylistic quirks don't seem so inexplicable any more. They just seem a little gross.

  1. According to Wikipedia , “the Bloomberg Terminal is available for an annual fee of around $24k per user or $27k per year for subscribers that use only one terminal. As of 2022, there were 325,000 Bloomberg Terminal subscribers worldwide.” That's about $8 billion per year in revenue. ↩︎

entry.summary: Two ways to automatically relaunch an app that's crashing in the background.
entry.content:
Item 1: Dropbox remains an excellent service, seemingly utterly reliable, with fair pricing.

Item 2: Dropbox's official Mac client has been a confusing, ugly, resource-heavy mess for years, and is only getting worse.

Item 3: Maestral is an open source Dropbox client for MacOS and Linux, developed by Sam Schott. It provides exactly what I want in a Mac Dropbox client, and what the official Dropbox app once was , long ago: a folder that syncs, with a minimal user interface that lives in a menu bar app. It uses far less memory than Dropbox's official client and offers a much simpler interface.

I switched from Dropbox's official Mac client to Maestral last August. Overall I've been very happy with the move. But Maestral is not for everyone. From Maestral's website, under “Limitations” :

Currently, Maestral does not support Dropbox Paper, the management of Dropbox teams and the management of shared folder settings. If you need any of this functionality, please use the Dropbox website or the official client.

Maestral uses the public Dropbox API which, unlike the official client, does not support transferring only those parts of a file which changed (“binary diff”). Maestral may therefore use more bandwidth that the official client. However, it will avoid uploading or downloading a file if it already exists with the same content locally or in the cloud.

I don't use Dropbox Paper, don't have a Dropbox “team”, and I'm fine going to the Dropbox website to manage shared folder settings. The only thing I miss from the official Dropbox client is the Finder contextual menu item to copy a sharing link to an item — but I need that seldom enough that I don't much mind doing that on the Dropbox website too.

Another big difference: the official Dropbox client is transitioning to MacOS's relatively new File Provider APIs . These are the APIs that allow cloud-based storage providers to keep certain files online-only, downloading the file locally only when you need it. I don't need or want that. I just want my entire Dropbox folder's contents to sync entirely. (Maestral does support Dropbox's “selective sync” to omit specified folders and files, but those omitted files don't show up at all in your local folder.) If you keep your Dropbox folder on an external hard drive, you might need to switch to Maestral, because Apple's File Provider APIs require folders to be stored in ~/Library/CloudStorage/ . With Maestral, your local Dropbox folder can be anywhere.

Bottom line: 11 months in, and I'm a very happy Maestral user.

But. For the last month or so, I've noticed that whenever I wake my Mac (an M1 MacBook Pro running MacOS Ventura 13.4.1), Maestral (version 1.7.3) is no longer running. It crashes silently in the background while my Mac is sleeping (or when waking up?). Here's an issue filed for the bug on GitHub , dittoed by half a dozen users. The obvious band-aid solution is to manually relaunch Maestral each time I wake my Mac, but that's annoying and easy to forget. The whole point of Dropbox is that it just works in the background, automatically.

While waiting for a fix in Maestral itself, here are two workarounds. They should be applicable in any situation where you want to automatically relaunch an app that is periodically crashing in the background.

Workaround 1: LaunchControl and launchd

launchd is Apple's longstanding (dating back to Mac OS X 10.4) system for running background processes, either on a schedule or triggered by events. The built-in way to manage launchd jobs is the launchctl command-line utility. 1 launchd is very nerdy and has a ton of features .

Enter Robby Pählig's LaunchControl : “a fully-featured launchd GUI allowing you to create, manage and debug system and user services on your Mac.” It costs $21 for a personal license and is worth every cent. LaunchControl is well-designed, comprehensive, and extensively-documented.

In my case, I wanted to create a new launchd job that will keep Maestral running at all times. When it crashes while my Mac is sleeping, I just want it to silently relaunch. Creating such a job using LaunchControl is trivial.

First, drag and drop the Maestral app onto the LaunchControl app icon. This will show a dialog box like this:

Click “For current user”. 2

就是这样。 This does exactly what we want by default: it creates a new user-only launchd job that keeps Maestral alive no matter what. If it crashes, it'll be relaunched. If we quit Maestral manually, it'll be relaunched.

One bit of manual fiddling I suggest is giving the job a descriptive name. By default, LaunchControl just names it “local.job”. I renamed mine “local.Maestral.keepalive”:

The file for this job (after renaming) lives at ~/Library/LaunchAgents/local.Maestral.keepalive.plist . But you never really need to deal with that file if you're using LaunchControl. If you ever want to trash it (eg after a version of Maestral ships with a fix for this bug), you can do so within LaunchControl itself.

Workaround 2: Keyboard Maestro and AppleScript

For anyone else out there running into this bug with Maestral 1.7.3, the LaunchControl/ launchd solution described above is all you need for a workaround. But the nerd in me wanted to know how often Maestral was crashing in the background. When Maestral crashes while my Mac is sleeping, it doesn't seem to leave any sort of log describing what happened or when.

So here's another workaround, this time using Keyboard Maestro and a tiny AppleScript. First, create a new global macro in Keyboard Maestro. I named mine “Maestral: Keep Alive”. Set it up like this:

The trigger is “Periodically while logged in”, running once a minute, all day, every day of the week. The action is this simple AppleScript:

 if application "Maestral" is not running then display notification (current date) as string ¬ with title "Maestral was not running" do shell script "/usr/bin/open /Applications/Maestral.app" end if

If Maestral is running when this script runs, nothing happens. If it isn't, the script displays a notification with the current date and time, and then launches Maestral. Sometimes I notice the notification appear after I wake my Mac, sometimes I don't. But I can go to Notification Center and see the whole stack of them to see how often it's occurring. (Turns out it gets triggered a dozen or so times overnight, every day.)

Astute scripters might wonder why I'm using do shell script "/usr/bin/open /Applications/Maestral.app" to launch Maestral, instead of the idiomatic tell application "Maestral" to launch .好问题。 The answer is that each time Keyboard Maestro runs this AppleScript, it needs to be compiled. And whenever an AppleScript is compiled, any applications targeted by tell blocks will be launched if they aren't already running. That's just a quirk of how AppleScript works, but in this particular case, it would defeat the entire purpose of the script, because when the script runs, Maestral would always be running, because if it weren't already running before the macro started executing, it would get launched when Keyboard Maestro compiled the script, which happens right before the script is actually run. So we relaunch Maestral with a one-line shell script instead.

  1. The standard POSIX cron utility is still supported on MacOS, but is deprecated in favor of launchd . ↩︎

  2. Which, to be a HIG pedant, ought to be title-cased : “For Current User”. ↩︎︎

entry.title: ★ Nerding Out With Maestral, LaunchControl, and Keyboard Maestro
Steven Soderbergh's 'Command Z'
entry.content:
Command Z is an eight-episode sci-fi time-travel parody directed by Steven Soderbergh, and distributed on its own website. It costs $8, and all proceeds are going to charity . It feels fair to describe it as a Soderbergh-ian take on Idiocracy . It debuted yesterday, 17 July 2023, which is cleverly meta insofar as that's the date the characters in the movie travel back in time to.

I enjoyed it — it was easily worth $8. It's lighthearted and well-cast, with some very funny throwaway jokes about the future the characters live in. But because it's only available through its own website, the only way to watch Command Z on a TV is via AirPlay, and that kind of sucks for something this long. Pause for too long and you can't just un-pause, you need to open your phone and start the AirPlay connection all over again. And even if you watch straight through without pausing, you need to fiddle with your phone between episodes. For watching on a phone, it's probably good that it's broken up into 8 short episodes, but for watching on TV via AirPlay, it'd be much better if you could just watch it straight through like a movie. The eight episodes vary in length from 7–20 minutes, but with a total running time of about 95 minutes, you can think of it as an eight-chapter movie.

I'd love to see more filmmakers shoot micro-budget indie projects like this, but there ought to be a better way to distribute them for consumption on TVs.

Update: I noticed, of course, that the series is titled Command Z , not Control Z . They even use the “⌘” glyph in the logotype. But while of course a man of Soderbergh's refined taste is a long-time Mac user , the fact that it's not Control Z is yet another sign that the Windows hegemony is over.

★

entry.title: 'Grid World'
entry.content:
Alex Miller:

An obsession was born. I was intoxicated by graph paper. The emptiness of a totally blank page intimidated me by demanding that I make the first move, but graph paper invited my participation by steering my pencil in the grooves of its strictly regular lines. The grid was like a friend who had already done half the work for me. I drew mazes, maps, patterns, plans — all held by the sturdiness of the grid. The effect was soothing. Through the grid's lattice, all my drawings, no matter how primitive, took on an air of rational certainty.

Around the same time that my dad showed me the grid map game, I started using a computer. In our house, down the carpeted stairs, in the basement, there was a light wood desk, upon which sat a beige plastic box with a rainbow striped Apple logo on the front: the Power Macintosh . Through this machine's chunky, low res monitor, I witnessed a grid come to life. Each pixel was a modular, addressable component in a digital whole. The windows, the buttons, the fonts, the menus, and the icons — oh, the icons! The world of the computer was filled with little hieroglyphic pictures representing folders, files, control panels, and drawing tools, each crisply rendered on the pixel grid of the screen. The logic and aesthetic of the grid permeated the virtual world of the computer — all rational, all peaceful.

This essay hit close to home. As a kid, I too was obsessed both with graph paper and computers, and intuited a deep connection between the two. ( Via The HTML Review , another nominee in The Tiny Awards .)

★

entry.title: The Tiny Awards
entry.content:
Andy Baio:

In May, the creators of two of my favorite newsletters, Naive Weekly and Web Curios , reached out to see if I'd consider joining the selection committee of Tiny Awards , a tiny prize to honor websites that “best embodies the idea of a small, playful and heartfelt web.” I loved the idea and quickly accepted.

There were some additional rules: sites must have launched in the last 12 months, work on mobile and desktop without requiring an app or download, made by individuals or a group of creators (ie not agencies or brands), and should be primarily non-commercial.

Nominations were free and open to the public, unlike some other web awards , and the selection committee ended up reviewing over 270 submissions , which we narrowed down to a shortlist of 16 finalists , a wonderfully eclectic collection of websites.

The winner is decided by public voting, which is also free and easy, and closes next Thursday, July 20. I hope you take a look and cast your vote . Here's a little about each of the finalists.

Personal favorites: Phil Gyford's Ooh.directory (“a place to find good blogs that interest you”, previously linked from here back in December ), and Acronymy , a dictionary in which every word is defined as an acronym. (And, yes, its definition for acronym is pretty good.)

★
